metadata.title: Weekly Python Digest for Data Science (1st Week July) | by Favio Vázquez | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Weekly Python Digest for Data Science (1st Week July)
metadata.description: This great open source code will let you use graph convolution to process input graphs, computes a scene layout by predicting bounding boxes and segmentation masks for objects, and convert the layout…

all_paragraphs: This great open source code will let you use graph convolution to process input graphs, computes a scene layout by predicting bounding boxes and segmentation masks for objects, and convert the layout to an image with a cascaded refinement network.
The paper can be found here:

So what does this code do? It implements an end-to-end neural network model that inputs a scene graph and outputs an image. A scene graph is a structured representation of a visual scene where nodes represent objects in the scene and edges represent relationships between objects.

The input scene graph is processed with a graph convolution network which passes information along edges to compute embedding vectors for all objects. These vectors are used to predict bounding boxes and segmentation masks for all objects, which are combined to form a coarse scene layout. The layout is passed to a cascaded refinement network which generates an output image at increasing spatial scales. The model is trained adversarially against a pair of discriminator networks which ensure that output images look realistic.
The original code was developed and tested on Ubuntu 16.04 with Python 3.5 and PyTorch 0.4. I tested in my Mac with no issues :)
I recommend you try this in a virtual environment. You can setup a virtual environment to run the code like this:
You’ll need to have python-venv install to follow this. Oh BTW I needed to change some of the script, this is what I used:
Oh! Also for some reason I needed to erase the pkg-resources=0.0.0 from the requirements.txt. It seems to be a bug:
I already created the Issue and PR :)
To run the pre-trained models you’ll need to download them by running the script bash scripts/download_models.sh. This will download the following models, and will require about 355 MB of disk space:
You can use the script scripts/run_model.py to easily run any of the pretrained models on new scene graphs using a simple human-readable JSON format.
To recreate the images of sheeps above you’ll have to run:
Let’s take a look into figure_6_sheep.json:
And let’s analyze the first one:
So we have sky, grass and a zebra, where the sky [0] is above the grass [1] and the zebra [2] is standing on the grass [1].
Let’s create a new one to test the code:
Programming is a must skill in Data Science, in this great repository, we will see the implementation of several important algorithms in full Python code.
These are for demonstration purposes only. There are many implementations of sorts in the Python standard library that are much better for performance reasons.
For example you’ll find Machine Learning codes, Neural Networks, Dynamic Programming, Sorts, Hashes and much more. For example this is K-means from scratch in Python with Numpy:

ML-Ensemble combines a Scikit-learn high-level API with a low-level computational graph framework to build memory efficient, maximally parallelized ensemble networks in as few lines of codes as possible.

ML-Ensemble is thread safe as long as base learners are and can fall back on memory mapped multiprocessing for memory-neutral process-based concurrency. For tutorials and full documentation, visit the project website.
ML-Ensemble is available on PyPI. Install with
Simple example (the iris obligated examples):
To check the performance of estimator in the layers, call the data attribute. The attribute can be wrapped in a pandas.DataFrame, but prints in a tabular format as is.
Not so bad. eLt’s see how the ensemble as a whole fared:
And that’s it for today :). Soon you’ll get more information, and posts with R too. If you want to stay updated please subscribe bellow:
Thanks for reading this. I hope you found something interesting here :)
If you have questions just follow me on Twitter
